This image, from a 15th-century French Book of Hours, of the Virgin adoring the naked Child in a glory of rays on the bare earth, reflects the influence of some important medieval imaginings of the Virgin Birth. These emphasize the miraculous speed, painlessness and spotlessness with which the Virgin Mary gave birth to Jesus, quite without all the pain and mess entailed by the Fall on all other women in labour and childbirth. The Meditationes Vitae Christi recounts how the Son of the Eternal God came out of the mothers womb without a murmur or lesion, in a moment
column2: as he had been in the womb, so he was now outside, on the hay at his mothers feet.

column1: In a vision during a pilgrimage to Bethlehem in 1370, St Bridget of Sweden (see Image 596) saw how Mary knelt down in prayer and became rapt in contemplation:
 And thane I saw in hir wombe a thinge stire
column2: and sodanli sho bare hir son. And thare came so grete a light and brightnes that it passed the brightenes of the sun, and the lightnes of the candill that Joseph sett on the wall might noght be sene. And it was so sodan, that beringe of the childe, that I might not persaive the passinge further of the childe. Nevirthless. I sawe that blissful childe liinge naked on the erthe, and he had the fairest skin that evir I sawe, withouten spot. Also I sawe the secondine [placenta], that is the rim that the childe was born in, liand all white. Than herde I sange of aungells wounder swete and likinge. And when the maiden felide that sho had born hir childe, she bowed doune hir heed and held up hir handes and worshiped the childe and saide to him: Welcom mi God, mi Lord, mi Son! (Liber Celestis, ed Roger Ellis, Oxford 1987, p.486).
